discussion.content: It is definitely B, %RDY is CPU Ready Percent, higher the value the worse it gets.

Interpreting CPU performance metrics
Ready, %RDY:
This value represents the percentage of time that the virtual machine is ready to execute commands, but has not yet been scheduled for CPU time due to contention with other virtual machines.
Compare against the Max-Limited, %MLMTD value. This represents the amount of time that the virtual machine was ready to execute, but has not been scheduled for CPU time because the VMkernel deliberately constrained it. For more information, see the Managing Resource Pools section of the vSphere Monitoring and Performance Guide or Resource Management Guide.
If the virtual machine is unresponsive or very slow and %MLMTD is low it may indicate that the ESX host has limited CPU time to schedule for this virtual machine.

comments.content: I will still go for B. C is for %WAIT -> Percentage of time the resource pool, virtual machine, or world spent in the blocked or busy wait state. Wheras %RDY is -> Percentage of time the resource pool, virtual machine, or world was ready to run.

discussion.content:
I would go for C:
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.monitoring.doc/GUID-AC5FAD2D-96DE-41C4-B5C6-A06FE65F34C6.html

%RDY Percentage of time the resource pool, virtual machine, or world was ready to run, but was not provided CPU resources on which to execute.
100% = %RUN + %RDY + %CSTP + %WAIT

questions.question_text: Which function key command will allow a vSphere administrator to access ESXi shell?
What are two uses of the vRealize Log Insight Agents for Windows and Linux? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: A and D. Passed with 500/500 today
AD is correct at exam. Passed with 500.

B & D
Applications can also store log data in flat text files on the file system. 
The vRealize Log Insight agent monitors event channels and directories and collects and forwards events from application log files.
Windows Agents:
1.The target vRealize Log Insight server to which the vRealize Log Insight Windows agent forwards events
2.The communication protocol and port that the agent uses.
3.Adding or removing Windows event channels.
Linux Agents:
1.The target vRealize Log Insight server to which the agent forwards events.
2.The directories that the agent monitors.

comments.content:
Thinking about "the Monitor the state of ... Services", it's not accurate.
So, I suggest to choose A & D.

discussion.content:
Correct A & D
Refer: Working with vRealize Log Insight Agents
Applications can also store log data in flat text files on the file system The vRealize Log Insight agent monitors event channels and directories and collects and forwards events from application log files.

AB is correct.

Seems you can monitor services
Seems you can monitor service with Log Insight 

http://www.vmignite.com/2016/02/log-insight-how-to-monitor-any-windows-service/

Agreed. The Agents do not perform any monitoring of "services" therefore B is incorrect.
Whereas configuring the monitoring of directories IS an option.
Correct answer is AD

choices.A: Collect events from flat text files.
choices.C: Control the state of the syslog/eventmgr services.
choices.B: Monitor the state of syslog/eventmgr services.

choices.A: LUN used a RDM must be visible to the underlying hosts in the cluster.
choices.B: LUN used as a RDM cannot be visible to any other underlying hosts in the cluster.
choices.D: LUN used as a RDM must be hidden to the ESXi host.
choices.C: VM resides on a VMFS datastore.
